oai_dc:dc.dc:title: States Rights Gist

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Gist, States Rights (1831- )
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Half-length portrait of Confederate Colonel States Rights Gist (1831-1864) seated in military uniform.

States Rights Gist was an active secessionist from South Carolina who achieved the rank of brigadier general in the state militia. In 1862 he was commissioned a brigadier general in the Confederate army and served at Vicksburg. He also served at Chickamauga, Chattanooga, and Atlanta. He was shot and killed during the Battle of Franklin in 1864.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Light infantry
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-quarter length portrait of Joe Weakley Sr., believed to be a "Dunlap Zouave." He wears a traditional Zouave uniform with kepi and has an infantry sword on his belt.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bob Ray
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The "Dunlap Zouaves" were first called to enlist in Nashville in 1861. Zouaves adopted the dress of North African French light infantry, some regiments selecting it as their standard uniform, others being awarded "Zouave" uniforms for particularly impressive service records.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Union Lieutenant Alfred C. Williams

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Uniforms; Portrait photographs
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Head and shoulders portrait of Lieutenant Alfred C. Williams in uniform. The photograph is hand-tinted.

Lietutenant Alfred C. Williams served in Company F of the 13th Regiment Tennessee Volunteers, USA. The native of Stoney Creek in Carter County was mustered in with the organization of the company on September 22, 1863, and achieved the rank of 2nd Lieutenant before resigning on September 26, 1864. His approximate age was 41, and he had experienced ill health throughout his military service. He later died in Elizabethton on August 28, 1900.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lafayette W. Bush in Confederate uniform
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Uniforms; Portrait photographs
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Half-length portrait of Lafayette Bush up wearing a Confederate uniform. The jacket is missing buttons and has a loose shoulder epaulet.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: [Vannerson, Julian, 1827-1875]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bush was a corporal in the 44th Tennessee Infantry, C.S.A. He was born April 17, 1843, in Davidson County, Tennessee. He enlisted December 30, 1861, in Nashville. His obituary states he professed religion at a soldier's meeting in New Market Heights, Virginia, in July 1864. Bush died in battle on September 29th, 1864, at Fort Harrison, Virginia. The 2500 attacking Federal soldiers captured the fort, and it was renamed Fort Burnham after the Federal general who was killed during the battle.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Fort Donelson (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-quarter length portrait of Colonel Frank N. McNairy in Confederate uniform. His right hand rests on the hilt of a sword and in his left he holds a slouch hat at his hip. Written beneath the image is, "Killed at the second battle of Fort Donelson."

McNairy was killed in the "Second Battle of Fort Donelson," the February 3, 1863, event when 2500 Confederate troops under Major General Joseph Wheeler attacked a small garrison (800 men) at Dover, Tennessee, under Colonel A.C. Harding. The Confederate failure to capture the garrison left Federals in control of Middle Tennessee. Nathan Bedford Forrest denounced Wheeler after this battle and refused to serve under him again.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Major General Alexander McDowell McCook
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; McCook, Alexander McDowell, 1831-1903
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Half length portrait of Alexander McDowell McCook, seated, wearing major general insignia and holding a sword in his left hand. The inscription reads: "Affectionately yr brother, A. McD. McCook, Maj. Genl."

Alexander McDowell McCook was a Federal general in the Civil War who served at the battles of Bull Run, Stones River, and Chickamauga. He also commanded the "Defenses of the Potomac River and Washington" and served in Arkansas. After the war he became commandant of the Command and General Staff College at Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, and served on a commission investigating the U. S. War Department after the Spanish-American War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms; Fences
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Antietam, Battle of, Md., 1862; Gardner, Alexander, 1821-1882
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three dead Confederate soldiers of Brigadier General William E. Starke's 2nd Louisiana Brigade. They fell near the fence along Hagerstown Turnpike in Maryland north of the Dunker Church during the Battle of Antietam.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Alexander Gardner
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Battle of Antietam, or Sharpsburg, was fought on September 17, 1862. The battle cost nearly 23,000 casualties and resulted in the end of Robert E. Lee's proposed invasion of Maryland. Brigadier General William Starke, a Virginian, was assigned the 2nd Louisiana Brigade. He and many of his men died at Antietam. Alexander Gardner was a Scotsman famous for his photographs of the Civil War and Abraham Lincoln.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Brigadier General Simon Bolivar Buckner
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Buckner, Simon Bolivar, 1823-1914
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Half-length portrait of Confederate General Simon Bolivar Buckner in uniform. Visible are the brigadier general insignia and a sword resting in his lap.

Simon Bolivar Buckner of Kentucky served in the Mexican-American War and taught infantry tactics at West Point. During the Civil War he accepted a Confederate commission after Kentucky could no longer maintain neutrality. He served at Fort Donelson and in General Bragg's abortive invasion of Kentucky. Buckner saw action at Perryville, Chickamauga, and Chattanooga. In 1887 he successfully ran for Governor of Kentucky. In 1896 he ran unsuccessfully for president on the National Democratic Party ticket.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Elijah Anderson, C.S.A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Grainger County (Tenn.); Shiloh, Battle of, Tenn. 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Gold-framed ambrotype of Confederate soldier Elijah Anderson (circa 1816-1862) in civilian clothes. Pinned to his left lapel is a ribbon displaying the name "Anderson."

Elijah Anderson was born circa 1816 in Grainger County, Tennessee. He lived in Cannon County, Tennessee, circa 1829-1858, before moving to Coffee County, Tennessee, circa 1859. He enlisted in the Confederate Army on either July 31, 1861, at Camp Anderson, or on August 24, 1861, at Camp Trousdale. A private in Company K of the 24th Tennessee Infantry Regiment, he reported sick to the hospital at Bowling Green, Kentucky, and later served at Shiloh, where he was wounded. He died of his wounds on April 17, 1862, in Corinth, Mississippi. Corinth was under Confederate control at the time of Elijah Anderson's death.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Brigadier General Thomas Benton Smith
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Shiloh, Battle of, Tenn., 1862; Stones River, Battle of, Murfreesboro, Tenn., 1862-1863; Chickamauga, Battle of, Ga., 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bust portrait of Brigadier General Thomas Benton Smith (1838-1923) in uniform wearing the rank of colonel.

An officer in the 20th Tennessee Infantry, Smith fought at Mill Springs, Shiloh, Baton Rouge, Stones River, Chickamauga, Atlanta, Dalton to Jonesborough, Franklin, Nashville, and Murfreesboro. He was promoted to brigadier general in 1864, suggesting the portrait must be pre-1864. Captured at the Battle of Nashville, he suffered long-term psychological damage stemming from a beating he received following his capture. He spent the last 47 years of his life in an insane asylum in Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aldehoff School during the Civil War
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Military bands; Military uniforms; Musical instruments; Military occupations; Tents; Military camps; Boarding schools; Schools; Soldiers; Military officers
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Federal officers, a regimental band with instruments, and several ladies pose in front of the two-story Aldehoff School. People can be seen in the windows of the building, and a tent appears in the right foreground of the dual-image stereograph card, a possible indication that Union forces are occupying the premises.

After coming to Chattanooga in 1850 and opening schools at several different locations, Henry W. von Aldehoff purchased the McCullough Hotel property on Lookout Mountain in order to operate a school large enough for boarding pupils. After the firing on Fort Sumter, school pupils lit barrels of coal tar, made secessionist speeches and sang. Boys and girls left the Institute to aid the war effort, and the school closed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Lockett, Samuel H. (Samuel Henry), 1837-1891; Vicksburg (Miss.) - History - Siege, 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Half-length portrait of Samuel Henry Lockett in Confederate uniform. He wears the insigna of a lieutenant colonel.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Washburn
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Samuel Henry Lockett was a Confederate engineer responsible for the defenses of Vicksburg. He later taught mathematics and science at Louisiana State University and the University of Tennessee at Knoxville. He also served as an engineer in the Egyptian Army and was involved with the construction of the Statue of Liberty.

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Half length portrait of Confederate Private Robert Archer Cheatham, First Tennessee Infantry. He wears a Confederate uniform and kepi.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert Brothers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Robert Archer Cheatham was the son of Col. Edward Saunders Cheatham, at one time Speaker of the Senate of Tennessee, and Jane Ellen Foster. Jane Ellen Foster Cheatham's father, Ephraim Hubbard Foster, was a senator from Tennessee. The photograph is reproduced from Calvert plate #312. The original was taken between 1861 and 1865. It was reprinted by Calvert Brothers in the 1890s.

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; United States - Army - Quartermaster Corps; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oval bust length portrait of Col. Jno. C. Crane, Inspector of Quarter Master's Department, in uniform. The portrait is signed, "Respectfully your [illegible], Jno. C. Crane, Col. Inspector Quartermaster Department. January 1, 1865." "James F. Rusling, Nash." is written in pencil on the lower front left corner outside the portrait area.
The Quartermaster Corps is responsible for keeping equipment and supplies functioning and available to the officers and their troops, and transporting supplies to new locations.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait photographs; Civil wars; Firearms; Knives; Arms & armament; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Confederate States of America. Army
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-quarter length portrait of Henry Howe Cook. Inscription on the back of the photograph reads, "Photo of Henry Howe Cook, Soldier of the C.S.A. in the War of the 1860's. He was later Chancellor of Davidson and Williamson Counties. He was born Nov. 23, 1843."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: William Gustav Thuss
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Henry Howe Cook fought with D Company of the Tennessee 1st Infantry and with the Tennessee 55th Infantry. He was wounded at Murfreesboro in 1862 and taken prisoner in Virginia in 1864. Named Chief Judge of Williamson County in 1882, he authored "Story of the Six Hundred," in the Confederate Veteran, Volume 6 (March 1898), page 120.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civil War soldiers at Lula Lake, Lookout Mountain
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Lookout Mountain (Tenn.); Lookout Mountain, Battle of, Tenn., 1863; Hamilton County (Tenn.); Chattanooga (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four soldiers seated on the rocks around Lula Lake, then known as Lake Solitude. Lula Falls can be seen in the background.

Following the Battle of Chickamauga, Lookout Mountain was garrisoned by the Confederate Army of Tennessee under Braxton Bragg. The Battle of Lookout Mountain in 1863 pushed the Confederates east and south, and the mountain remained in Federal hands until the war's end. The soldiers pictured appear to be in Federal dress, so it can be assumed the photograph was taken after 1863.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hospital Yard, Nashville
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Military hospitals; Laundry; Women; Photographs; Military life; Military hospitals; Clotheslines; Laundresses
Civil War America; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Hospitals
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scene in the yard of a military hospital in Nashville, showing numerous men and women, some African American, among lines of hanging laundry.

During the Civil War, hundreds of hospitals were established in cities and towns in both the North and the South. Some were specifically designed and built for that purpose, but others occupied existing buildings taken over for hospital use. Conditions in Civil War hospitals were grim and overcrowded, particularly after battles. Diseases spread rapidly, even though soldiers with contagious illnesses were separated from those who were wounded.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Half-length portrait of Sergeant James Otey Gloster, C.S.A., in uniform. A note on the back of the photograph states that it was a gift of Dr. Digby Seymour of LaGrange, Illinois.
Sergeant James Otey Gloster was in Company G of the Tennessee 13th Volunteer Infantry (The Gaines Invincibles). He was killed in action at the Battle of Murfreesboro.

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Men of Rutledge's Battery posed in front of a tent. They are identified as Frank Johnson, George W. Trabue, Jack R. Long, Jason C. Wheeler, E. F. Falconet, A. M. Rutledge, Joe E. Harris, George E. Purvis, J. P. Humphrey, J. Griffith, and M. S. Cockrill. An inscription at the bottom reads: "To Mrs. Watkins Compliments of Geo. E. Purvis."
The Rutledge Tennessee Battery of six guns participated in the Battle of Shiloh as part of Statham's 3rd Brigade of Breckinridge's Corps of the Confederate Army of Mississippi.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Officers of the 1st Regiment Tennessee Infantry, Volunteers of African Descent
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Photographs; Soldiers; Armies; Montages; Military officers
African American soldiers - History - 19th Century; United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865, African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Composite of the officers of the 1st Regiment Tennessee Infantry, Volunteers of African Descent, United States Army.

The United States Colored Troops (U.S.C.T.) in Tennessee experienced every facet of war between 1863 and 1865. In the spring of 1863, General Lorenzo Thomas was appointed Commissioner for the Organization of Colored Troops for the Federal Army in Tennessee. He began actively raising black regiments in Memphis and had 3,000 troops by June. These first regiments were designated by state and race, such as the 1st Tennessee Volunteers Infantry Regiment, A. D. (African Descent). This unit was organized June 18, 1863, at LaGrange, Fayette County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: U.S. Quartermaster warehouse in Nashville. Men, including several African Americans, can be seen in open warehouse doors. The Capitol and several downtown buildings stand silhouetted in the background.

The quartermaster was responsible for supplying the army with clothing, transportation, horses, equipment, tents, lumber, fuel and any other supplies necessary for the army to move effectively. The warehouse in Nashville was located near the center of town.

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; United States - Army - Quartermaster Corps; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unfinished forage house in Nashville, Tennessee, with a group of officers of the Quartermaster Department. An inscription beneath the photograph reads, "Forage House on N. and NW. RR. Nashville, Tenn. - DIMENSIONS. 1st Sec 904 by 156 ft wide; 2d Sec 805 by 112 ft wide Only 201ft 2d finished leaving 604 ft in an unfinished state. FRONT VIEW EAST Group of Officers QMDept Nashville."

A forage house was used to store hay and oats for the Army's horses and mules. The Quartermaster Corps is responsible for keeping equipment and supplies functioning and available to the officers and their troops, and transporting supplies to new locations as needed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Military depots; Military life; People; Wooden buildings; Historic buildings; Storehouses; Warehouses; Guards; Standing
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; United States - Army - Quartermaster Corps; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Rear view of Eaton Depot with a soldier standing guard. The Capitol, Downtown Presbyterian Church and Maxwell House Hotel are visible in the background. An inscription in the lower left corner reads, "James F. Rusling, Nash."

The Federal Army, fresh from its victory at Fort Donelson, occupied Nashville in February 1862. Andrew Johnson was appointed military governor a month later. Nashville remained in Union hands for the duration of the war. James Fowler Rusling, an attorney in civilian life, was 3rd Corps Quartermaster, promoted to Inspector of the Quartermaster Department of the U.S.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Men; Soldiers

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Granbury, Hiram Bronson, 1831-1864; Fort Donelson, Battle of, Tenn., 1862; Franklin, Battle of, Franklin, Tenn., 1864
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bust portrait of a young Hiram Bronson Granbury.

H. B. (Hiram Bronson) Granbury (1831-1864) was born in Waco, Texas. He served at Fort Donelson, where he was captured but then freed in a prisoner exchange. He served at Chickamauga and Missionary Ridge and was one of the six Confederate generals killed during the Battle of Franklin in 1864.

This was a commissary warehouse located in the vicinity of 6th Avenue South and Lafayette Street. James Fowler Rusling, an attorney in civilian life, was 3rd Corps Quartermaster, promoted to Inspector of the Quartermaster Department of the U.S. The Quartermaster Corps is responsible for keeping equipment and supplies functioning and available to the officers and their troops, and transporting supplies to new locations as needed.

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Arrangers (Musicians)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bust portrait of W. R. McQuown in civilian clothing. An inscription beneath the image reads, "4th Ky. Regt., C.S.A./ Col. Lewis Regt./ W. R. McQuown." An inscription on the back reads, "Leader of the 4th Ky. Regt and the 1st Tenn Band until the surrender in 1865. First cousin of Geo. S. Nichols."
W. R. McQuown was a mid-19th century composer best known for the "Cadet's March," which he dedicated to the Kentucky State Guard.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Hooker at Lookout Valley Headquarters with generals and staff

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Military headquarters; Log cabins; Military officers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Hooker, Joseph, 1814-1879
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Union General Joseph Hooker with generals and staff. Hooker appears as the central figure (Number 3); Number 2 is General Daniel Butterfield; Number 1 is General John W. Geary; and Number 4 is General William G. Le Duc. A Capt. Hall and Capt. Kibler are also in the photo. All are pictured in front of log cabins with canvas roofs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: [Linn, J. B.]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: After the defeat of the U.S. Army at the Battle of Chickamauga, President Lincoln sent General Hooker with forces to help break the Confederate siege of Chattanooga. General Grant and General George Thomas joined to help establish a new supply line. Hooker took Lookout Valley as Thomas prepared to break out of Chattanooga. Hooker then took Lookout Mountain and continued to pursue retreating Confederates. He remained headquartered in Lookout Valley until the Atlanta Campaign in May 1864.

This was a commissary warehouse (1st section: 287 ft long x 190 ft wide, 2 stories high; 2nd section 230 ft long x 190 ft Wide, 2 stories high). It was located near 6th Avenue South and Lafayette Street, Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Men; Soldiers
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Shiloh, Battle of, Tenn, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Half-length tintype portrait of George A. Nichols (1845-1914) after losing his left eye at the Battle of Shiloh. He wears a civilian white shirt and dark jacket. The photograph is set in a decorative gilt gold frame.

Nichols was a participant in the Battle of Shiloh which took place April 6-7, 1862. Ulysses S. Grant and the Union Army of the Tennessee defeated the Confederate Army of Mississippi under Albert Sidney Johnston and P. G. T. Beauregard. Johnston was killed during the battle, along with nearly 3500 others.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Sterling Price
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Price, Sterling, 1809-1867
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bust portrait of Confederate General Sterling Price in uniform.

Sterling "Old Pap" Price, born in Virginia in 1809, served in the Mormon War of Missouri and the Mexican-American War. Commissioned a major general by the Confederacy in 1862, he participated in several battles in the Western Theater, mostly in Missouri and Arkansas. He led a daring raid from Arkansas into Missouri in 1864 but was beaten back and forced to retreat to Texas. Price was the leader of the failed Confederate colony in Carlota, Veracruz. He died of cholera in 1867.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First Federal troops scaling Roper's Rock following the Battle of Lookout Mountain
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cliffs; Mountains; Soldiers; Ladders

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865 - Campaigns; Lookout Mountain, Battle of, Tenn., 1863; Chattanooga (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Federal troops employing ladders and scaling cliffs at Roper's Rock at the north end of Lookout Mountain near Chattanooga following the Battle of Lookout Mountain.

The Battle of Lookout Mountain or the "Battle Above the Clouds," commenced on November 24, 1863, with General Braxton Bragg's Confederate forces in possession of Lookout Mountain. Before daylight the next morning, and in opposition to the wishes of commander General Ulysses S. Grant, Federal volunteers scaled the cliffs of the Palisades, found the Confederates had withdrawn, and claimed Lookout Mountain. The rock was named after U. S. Sergeant Roper, who fell to his death there.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Braxton Bragg
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1865; Bragg, Braxtion, 1817-1876
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bust portrait of young General Braxton Bragg in uniform.

Bragg was born in North Carolina in 1817. He served in the Second Seminole War in Florida and the Mexican-American War. During the U.S. Civil War, Bragg commanded the Confederate Army of Mississippi and Army of Tennessee. He operated in a command capacity during the battles of Shiloh, Stones River, Chickmauga, and Chattanooga among others. He died in Texas in 1876.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General John C. Breckinridge
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Breckinridge, John C. (John Cabell), 1821-1875
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bust portrait of General John C. Breckinridge in uniform.

John C. Breckinridge, born in Kentucky in 1821, practiced law before being elected U.S. Representative in 1855. In 1857, he became vice president under James Buchanon and, in 1861, was elected U.S. senator. He served in the Mexcan-American War and was a major general in the Confederate Army during the Civil War, where he served at Stones River, Chickamauga, and Chattanooga. In 1865, Breckinridge served as the Confederate secretary of war. He died in 1875.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Grant on Lookout Mountain

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Trees

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History- Civil War, 1861-1865; Grant, Ulysses S. (Ulysses Simpson), 1822-1885; Rawlins, John A. (John Aaron), 1831-1869; Webster, J. D. (Joseph Dana), 1811-1876; Lagow, Clark B., d. 1867
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: General Ulysses S. Grant on Lookout Mountain near Missionary Ridge in 1863. Four men in uniform pose near the edge of the cliff, while one sits further back on the path. The other four are identified, left to right, as General John A. Rawlins, General J. D. Webster, Colonel Clark B. Lagow, and Colonel Killyer.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Lookout Mountain (Tenn.); Hamilton County (Tenn.); Missionary Ridge (Tenn. and Ga.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Following the Battle of Chickamauga, Lookout Mountain was garrisoned by the Confederate Army of Tennessee under Braxton Bragg. The Battle of Lookout Mountain in 1863 pushed the Confederates east and south, and the mountain then remained in Federal hands until the war's end. General Grant commanded the Federal victories at Lookout Mountain and Missionary Ridge on November 24-25 and drove the Confederates from their siege of Chattanooga.

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Steamboats; United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Military side-wheel steamboat, probably an ironclad, at dock. Its smokestack has collapsed. Soldiers are seen aboard the vessel.

Such side-wheel steamboats were modified for military use in the Civil War with reinforcements of timber, iron, or tin added to each deck. In the case of this vessel, the open area near the pilot house may have taken a hit from a cannonball.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Steamboats; Gunboats; Sailors; Navies; Vessels; Naval warfare; Warships
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Steamboats; Gunboats; United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Rivers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: US Navy warship, the USS Vindicator, with soldiers on the top deck in front of the wheel boxes and on the bow. There is a cannon on the stern and three smaller boats tied to the USS Vindicator.

Many existing side-wheel steamboats were modified for miltary use in the Civil War with reinforcements of timber, iron, or tin being added to the decks. This vessel was not armored at all and used its heavy guns and ram prow to handle Confederate warships.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Northern Bank of Alabama in Huntsville during Federal occupation
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Banks; Flags; Soldiers; Buildings; Guards; Plazas
Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Indiana - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Alabama - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front and side views of the Northern Bank of Alabama flying United States flag under Federal military occupation. Numerous uniformed soldiers and guards stand in front of the building.

Located on the south corner of West Side Square, the Northern Bank of Alabama is pictured flying the United States flag after occupation by Federal troops. Federl troops first seized Huntsville on April 11, 1862, but were forced to retreat several months later. During the autumn of 1863, occupation forces settled in for the duration of the war. Huntsville escaped large-scale damage because it functioned as a Federal base of operations and housed segments of the Federal Army.

Civil War America; United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Gardner, Alexander, 1821-1882; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Full-length portrait of two men serving as members of the Army of the Potomac. Both men are in full uniform.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gardner, Alexander
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: During the American Civil War, the Army of the Potomac was the North's primary army operating in the East. Organized in July 1861, this force confronted the Confederacy's Army of Northern Virginia throughout the conflict. Alexander Gardner (October 17, 1821- December 10, 1882) was a Scotsman and best known for his photographs of the Civil War, President Abraham Lincoln, and the execution of the conspirators to Lincoln's assassination.

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Benjamin Franklin Ammons (at right, wearing trews) and Raiford Franklin Ammons (at left) of the 1st Tennessee Heavy Artillery, C.S.A., seated in uniform holding their weapons. Portrait includes letter with narrative.

On June 10, 1864, at the Battle of Brices Crossroads in Mississippi, Raiford Franklin Ammons was shot in the left arm and it was amputated that day. At the time, he was enlisted with the 18th (Newson's) Tennessee Cavalry Regiment [per Mr. Ammons' letter in folder with photograph].

Civil War America; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Thompson, Meriwether Jeff, 1826-1876; Missouri--History; Missouri--History--Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-quarter length portrait of Missouri State Guard Colonel Meriwether Jeff Thompson in uniform.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: A. L'arcombe
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Meriwether Jeff Thompson (January 22, 1826- September 5, 1876) became a brigadier general in the Missouri State Guard during the American Civil War. He also served the Confederate Army as a cavalry commander, and had the unusual distinction of having a ship in the Confederate Navy named for him. Thompson organized the Missouri troops called the "Swamp Rats."

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-quarter legth tintype of Frederick Claybrooke. It is set in a hinged oval case. The text states that he was killed at Hoover's Gap while leading his regiment into battle.

The Battle of Hoover's Gap was the opening battle of the Tullahoma Campaign. On June 24, 1863, Union General Williams Rosecrans, hoping to capitalize on the victory at Stones River, dispatched forces to Hoover's Gap. There, the Federals-including John T. Wilder's Lightning Brigade-quickly drove the defenders out. Fighting continued until June 26.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Newton Sligar, Company C, 5th (McKenzie's) Tennessee Cavalry Regiment
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait photographs; Soldiers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Half-legth portrait of John Newton Sligar, Company C, 5th (McKenzies) Tennessee Cavalry Regiment.

The 5th (McKenzie’s) Tennessee Cavalry Regiment was organized on December 10, 1862, by adding two companies to the 13th (McKenzie’s) Tennessee Cavalry Battalion, originally 1st (Rogers’) East Tennessee Cavalry Regiment. In October and December 1862, two independent companies of cavalry were ordered by General Bragg to report to the 13th (McKenzie's) Tennessee Cavalry Battalion. By order of the secretary of war, the battalion was raised to a regiment and officially designated as the 5th (McKenzie's) Tennessee Cavalry Regiment on December 16, 1862.
